clinical_study.brief_title: Perioperative Pain and Delirium in Geriatric Patients With Hip Fracture
clinical_study.official_title: Correlation Between Perioperative Pain and Delirium in Geriatric Patients With Hip Fracture

brief_summary.textblock: The objective of this trial will be to establish whether the ultrasound-guided suprainguinal fascia iliaca compartment block is capable of protecting geriatric patients with hip fracture from delirium as compared to placebo

detailed_description.textblock:
Geriatric patients suffer from hip fractures very often. Delirium is a perioperative neuropsychiatric complication that is characterized by sudden change of mental status, inattention, disorientation and memory impairment with fluctuations of symptoms during the day. Delirium causes increased morbidity and mortality, decreased postoperative functional activity and may predispose to dementia.
Perioperative pain may be an important predisposing factor to delirium. Intravenous opioids have been widely used to relieve patients with hip fracture from pain, but they have a lot of complications and have been correlated with delirium as well. Fascia Iliaca compartment block is a peripheral compartment nerve block that is used in hip surgeries. Use of this compartment nerve block to protect geriatric patients from delirium has not been studied.
The objective of this trial will be to establish whether the ultrasound-guided suprainguinal fascia iliaca compartment block is capable of protecting geriatric patients with hip fracture from delirium as compared to placebo

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: pain score 30 minutes after fascia iliaca block
primary_outcome.time_frame: 30 minutes after performance of fascia iliaca block
primary_outcome.description: pain score by the use of Numeric Rating Scale (NRS) 30 minutes after fascia ilaca block, ranging from 0 to 10, where 0 means "no pain" and 10 means "worst pain imaginable"

primary_outcome.measure: pain score 12 hours after fascia iliaca block
primary_outcome.time_frame: 12 hours after performance of fascia iliaca block
primary_outcome.description: pain score by the use of Numeric Rating Scale (NRS) 12 hours after fascia ilaca block, ranging from 0 to 10, where 0 means "no pain" and 10 means "worst pain imaginable"

secondary_outcome.measure: pain score 1-8 days after fascia iliaca block
secondary_outcome.description: pain score by the use of Numeric Rating Scale (NRS) 1-8 days after fascia ilaca block, ranging from 0 to 10, where 0 means "no pain" and 10 means "worst pain imaginable"

other_outcome.description: Mini Mental State examination on arrival to the emergency room
Confusion Assessment Method on arrival to the emergency room

arm_group.arm_group_label: fascia iliaca compartment block with ropivacaine
arm_group.description: in this arm, the fascia iliaca compartment block will be performed with 40 mL ropivacaine 0.25%

arm_group.arm_group_label: fascia iliaca compartment block with placebo
arm_group.description: in this arm, the fascia iliaca compartment block will be performed with 40 mL normal saline

intervention.intervention_name: fascia iliaca compartment block with ropivacaine
intervention.description: the fascia iliaca compartment block catheter will be placed with the use of ultrasound till the day of surgery. Bolus doses will be given every 12 hours (40 ml of ropivacaine 0.25%)
intervention.arm_group_label: fascia iliaca compartment block with ropivacaine

intervention.intervention_name: fascia iliaca compartment block with placebo
intervention.description: the fascia iliaca compartment block catheter will be placed with the use of ultrasound till the day of surgery. Bolus doses will be given every 12 hours (40 ml of normal saline)
intervention.arm_group_label: fascia iliaca compartment block with placebo

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- geriatric patients
- American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) I-III
- hip fracture patients
Exclusion Criteria:
- dementia
- communication or language barriers
- patients with nutritional problems
- bedridden patients
